descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
TVF 360 - 24 Passing the Bechdel-Wallace Test: Writing Significant Roles for Women
Tuesdays 12:00 - 2:50 pm

Enrollment:  Prerequisite: RTVF 260 Foundations of Screenwriting or permission of the instructor.  Enrollment is limited to 12 students. Attendance at the first class is mandatory.

Contact info: r-gilman@northwestern.edu

Description:
In her 1985 cartoon, Dykes to Watch Out For, Alison Bechdel illustrated a test for films that came to her by way of her friend, Liz Wallace. Wallace told Bechdel that she would only see a movie if it satisfied three basic requirements. First, the movie had to have at least two women in it. Second, those two women had talk to each other. And third, that conversation had to be about something besides a man. These requirements have come to be known as the Bechdel-Wallace Test - a test which many films, television shows, and plays routinely fail. (In 2015, women accounted for only a third of speaking characters in films, and comprised only 22% of protagonists.) In this class we will aim to write scripts with leading roles for women - roles that are complicated, unique, and significant. We will do so by first examining traditional representations of women in all three media. We will then compare those representations to more contemporary portrayals and ask two essential questions: how far have we come in writing roles for women and how far do we have to go? The class will include screenings of films, televisions shows and readings of plays that co-opt genre (Meek's Crossing, Bridesmaids), challenge gender norms (Women Eating Salad Alone and Laughing), and expand traditional definitions of what it is to be a woman (Broad City, Girls, The Wolves, Orange is the New Black). The class will also include readings of essays and criticism from canonical and contemporary feminist theorists, as well as exercises in how to create rich characterizations.

These readings, lectures, discussion, screenings, and short writing assignments will lead to the development of a final project:
? Undergraduate students will be required to write the first 30 pages and a complete outline of a full-length screenplay, play, or original pilot.
? Graduate students will be required to complete a full-length screenplay, play, or pilot and show bible.

Required texts:
Crimes of the Heart, by Beth Henley Dramatists Play Service ISBN: 978-0822202509
Milk Like Sugar, by Kirsten Greenidge Samuel French ISBN: 978-0573700361

All films and television shows will be screened via Canvas.
All other texts will be handouts.
